body: Wow, a 5000 line change... I'll take a look this weekend...

@guozhangwang  thanks, I agree in practice it will mostly be random or evenly distributed, but that depends on luck... sometimes it will not. 
one thing I am wondering is the existing code is trying to do some 'round-robin' but actually not doing what it plans to do.

There was one test failure (`StreamsSmokeTest.test_streams`) in https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/615, but I think the failure is unrelated since yesterday's system test run on trunk also had the same failure (https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka/413).

Yes, that test seems to fail transiently and there's a PR for it: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2149

Merging this to trunk.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM.
Merged to trunk. The change didn't merge cleanly in the 0.10.1 branch. @enothereska, would you like to submit the same change to 0.10.1 as well?

With @dguy's help, we worked out the change that was causing the failing test in Streams: we now pass `MockTime` instead of `SystemTime` to `GroupCoordinator` (since we now use a single `Time` instance in `KafkaServer` whereas before we used `SystemTime` for any class that required the clients `Time` interface).

The root cause seems to be that `MockTime` is not thread-safe. After fixing that, the test seems to pass. When running it locally in a loop, I still get the occasional failure due to a ZK connect timeout, but that cannot be related to this PR as far as I can see.
@guozhangwang how does this look to you?
@ijuma thanks. Probably there is no need to put in 0.10.1, but I can submit I suppose.
@enothereska, we run system test builds for 0.10.1 on a nightly basis, so it would be good to avoid transient failures in that branch too.

LGTM
\cc @guozhangwang

This method is deprecated and this change would break compatibilty with anyone that actually managed to use it.  As discussed with @ijuma closing this without merge.  Change is linked if its needed to be revived for some reason in the future.
@miguno @enothereska @dguy @hjafarpour @guozhangwang

@becketqin, that's a fair point about the rename and introducing a new concept. I have similar concerns and was wondering how we could make things clearer without that. Your suggestion looks promising.
Ok @ijuma https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2154 Thanks.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM. I merged it to 0.10.1. Can you please close the PR? Auto-closing only works for trunk.
Other than my comment about `testNo` I'm +1.  Up to you folks to decide whether you like the `testNo` setup or not.
Does it make sense to separate the renaming from the actual task of this patch?
Hi! Thanks for merging this. When will the 2.12 version be published on Maven Central?
I looked through the client side code and I think we do not need to add the `describe` yet until we are about to remove the old server side code. So I'm happy to merge it if @hachikuji agreed.
One minor comment on logging, otherwise LGTM.

1. About "Setting a new key might result in an internal data redistribution if a key based operator (like an aggregation or join) is applied to the result {@link KStream}." and "Setting a new value preserves data co-location with respect to the key. Thus, no internal data redistribution is required if a key based operator (like an aggregation or join)" and "Because a new key is selected, an internal repartitioning topic will be created in Kafka." I think these explanations are a bit sparse and we could instead centralize them by giving an example in the `groupBy` function as well as `join`, saying that if the `KStream` is not directly from a source topic AND its key has changed in previous operators, the library will automatically re-write it by adding an intermediate topic, equally as `... through ...` with the repartition topic name conventions etc, blah blah. And then for other functions just say `c.f. `. 2. About "Keep in mind, that the result depends on the non-deterministic processing order of the input streams because..." I'd suggest rather mentioning this in web docs rather than in java docs. Otherwise LGTM.

About (1) -- `groupBy` and `join` do have an extensive explanation. Adding a `c.f. <link>` is a good idea. But I do not see why we should remove this short "hint"? Is there any disadvantage keeping those?

About (2) -- IMHO, it is good to also mention it in the JavaDocs. We should just describe the behavior such that a developer can get all required information from the JavaDocs.

What do you think @miguno @enothereska @dguy @hjafarpour ?
@ijuma I have updated the PR. Would you mind taking another look?
@pengwei-li : Sorry for the late response. It seems that the same issue has been fixed in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4360? If so, could you close this PR?
@hachikuji : I have updated the patch with additional comments. Would you mind taking another look?
@junrao @jjkoshy please review this PR. Thanks.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM.
Thanks @guozhangwang

I ran system tests on the latest patch and everything looks good: http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2016-11-22--001.1479824556--hachikuji--KAFKA4390--24dc7ed/report.html. I will probably continue to add some additional test cases, but I'll leave the rest as is pending further review comments.
Merged to trunk.

1) I just feel that the explanations are a bit sparse across different functions, and I'd suggest keeping it centralized, e.g. in one of the join operators and one of the aggregation operators, and in that explanation list the operators that could possibly change the key; and then in the operators that could possibly change the key add a one liner "hint" and refer to these two functions for long explanation. But probably you are already doing similar things (reviewing the plain text was a bit hard for me), so your call.

2) that depends on whether we view it as the essence of Streams or it is just a tech drawback that we would try to improve or even eliminate in the future; for the former case then it is fine but I was thinking it is actually the latter case.

@ijuma `def serverConfigName(configName: String): Option[String]=serverDefaultConfigNames.get(configName)` is not the same because it requires knowing the `LogConfig` keys beforehand. I need to iterate over the entire map and access all the key-value pairs. Recall that the idea is to get all the Kafka server configs that are applicable at topic level. If there's a new config tomorrow, ability to iterate will allow will absorb it right-away.
@sutambe, the log keys are already exposed via `LogConfig.configNames`. Why doesn't that work?
@ijuma @hachikuji : Thanks a lot for the detailed reviews :) I have tried to address most of the concerns on the PR. Please let me know any more changes are required :)
Call for review @dguy @enothereska

Thanks for your PR. I was just reading the JIRA and was wondering if you know about this change in Kafka Streams `0.10.1.0`: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-71%3A+Enable+log+compaction+and+deletion+to+co-exist

Streams does exploit this new feature and changelog topics do have a retention time already on top of being compacted. I would assume, this does solve your inital problem?

Furthermore, it is possible (`trunk` only, will be part of `0.10.2`) to plug a custom state store within DSL: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3825

Nevertheless, you PR could still get merger. However, we might need to get a KIP first: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Kafka+Improvement+Proposals

@guozhangwang @dguy @enothereska WDYT?
@raghavgautam can you upmerge this patch. I'll merge it in today.

@amethystic : Thanks for the patch. An alternative approach is to fix AbstractServerThread such that it's always shutdownable. For example, in AbstractServerThread, we could initialize shutdownLatch with CountDownLatch(0) and in startupComplete(), set shutdownLatch to CountDownLatch(1).

@junrao 
Thanks for the review. 
Regarding "Is the issue that the older replica not receiving LeaderAndIsrRequest when switching the leader reproducible? If so, should we file a separate jira to track that?"
---> Yes that is indeed the issue because we are treating the old replica similar to an offline partition in "electLeaderForPartition(...)" call. I will create a separate jira for it and fix it. 
I can then refactor this code to see if the code to clear the cache in stop replica is needed or not.
Does that sound good?
@harshach I have rebased my pull request

@MayureshGharat : That sounds good. It's probably ok to leave the logic for handling StopReplicaRequest there to be more defensive. A quick look at electLeaderForPartition() suggests that the leaderAndIsrRequest will be sent to all assigned replicas, which should include the old replicas. So, not sure if this is indeed the problem. But if you can figure that out, just put the details in a separate jira.

@junrao : sure will do. 
A quick reference : 
val (leaderAndIsr, **replicas**) = leaderSelector.selectLeader(topicAndPartition, currentLeaderAndIsr) in PartitionStateMachine.electLeaderForPartition(...) , the **replicas** returned by ReassignedPartitionLeaderSelector.selectLeader() is **only the new Replicas**, which are then sent the LeaderAndIsrRequest. So the old replica never receives this LeaderAndIsr.

I will create a new jira and explain this in detail. :)
@baluchicken can you address the above comments.
@hachikuji : I have added more details to the comment. Can you take another look?
LGTM
Btw, I was thinking we should double commit this to the 0.10.1 branch. Thoughts?
@hachikuji : Will also take a look at the patch. Just a quick note. Could you do some performance test to make sure there is no regression?

@MayureshGharat Thanks for the updates! LGTM. 

@ijuma Committing to 0.10.1 sounds like a good idea.
@junrao Thanks for taking a look. Performance testing is next on my plate after I fill in some of the gaps in test coverage.

@junrao Agreed, but something to be considered: Firstly, since this patch only affects the code path when the socket is already bound, it's much easier to reason about the effects. Modifying AbstractServerThread might need a thorough test covering all code paths. Secondly, initializing shutdownLatch with CountDownLatch(0) does not actually keep in line with ShutdownableThread behavior, so we might need to modify ShutdownableThread too. Does this make any sense?
@ijuma Agreed. Added `def serverConfigName`. Restored `private class LogConfigDef` and `private val configDef`.

@MayureshGharat  Thanks for the patch. Merged to trunk and 0.10.1

@hachikuji @ijuma @junrao Thanks for the review.
@junrao  yes , this bug also fixed by Kafka-4360,  close this PR is OK
@ijuma can you please review?
Thanks, LGTM. Will merge to trunk and 0.10.1 branches.
For the record, tweaked the test formatting slightly before merging.

If using a window store, then the window retention plus KIP-71 mentioned above should suffice. However, if it is a KV store there is currently no way to expire the entries.
If we were to use the TtLDB we'd also need to know when an entry expires so that we can send <key:null> to the compacted topic.

> Streams does exploit this new feature and changelog topics do have a retention time already on top of being compacted. I would assume, this does solve your inital problem?

@mjsax I'm aware of [KIP-71](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-71%3A+Enable+log+compaction+and+deletion+to+co-exist), but as @dguy said, it's only for windowded stores, but I'm having several other toplogies (streams apps), that are using left join, which is backed by a regular KV RocksDB state store. In those cases also, I don't need state store data forever - usually depends on the use case, but right now I'm having use cases where I need retention of 5 hours and 48 hours respectively.

> Furthermore, it is possible (trunk only, will be part of 0.10.2) to plug a custom state store within DSL: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3825

That's great news, this will surely help Kafka Streams users to have more choices regarding their particular needs, for example, some use cases don't need so fast processing, and you could use a regular company database for "local state". One great thing about custom state stores, is that you could chain RocksDB for relatively new messages, and have a fallback to a company database - for late arriving messages. With this you could tune you processing latency and storage requirements depending on the use case.

> If we were to use the TtLDB we'd also need to know when an entry expires so that we can send key:null to the compacted topic.

@dguy are you sure about that? That would mean that you would delete data from Kafka topic, based on some streams app use cases. Let's imagine that that you have two streams apps that have different use cases, but they use the same topic.
_App1_
_App2_
shared topic name: _inventory_
In _App1_ you do a left join to the topic _inventory_ - a new KV state store is created which is backed by this same topic _inventory_. In this app you configure `rocksdb.ttl.sec` because you don't need all the data all the time in the state store.
In _App2_ you do use _inventory_ as a stream, for every change, you apply some bussiness logic.

In this scenario, _App1_ specific use case and it's storage requirements would cause data to be deleted from a topic _inventory_ that maybe you don't won't to be deleted.

> Nevertheless, you PR could still get merger. However, we might need to get a KIP first: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Kafka+Improvement+Proposals

Before writing the KIP I would like to get consensus, that this change is needed and that my current implementation is going in the right direction. Regardless, I'm currently using forked version of Kafka Streams which contains this change. But I would like to get rid of this fork, and use the official version.

What do you think about my suggestion in **Suggestion for future work** paragraph?
@pengwei-li : Thanks. It seems that only you can close this PR.
@dguy could you have a look too if you get a chance? Thanks.

@jjkoshy Summarizing our discussion and decision to use the existing background thread-pool for deleting logs. The dilemma was between two choices with the existing background scheduler: 1) single-shot scheduling via `.schedule()` of a `task` to delete a single directory (topic-partition) and 2) periodic scheduled task to delete queued logs. Single-shot scheduling, although simpler, is dangerous because a boatload of deleted topic-partitions may hog the entire background thread-pool for just deletions, starving other periodic tasks including, log-retention, log-flusher, and recovery-point-checkpoint. 

An alternative thread-pool of background threads could be used but it requires a separate user-facing config and was therefore eliminated.

A periodically scheduled deletion task (option 2 above) has two sub-options: a) scan the directory looking for any directories marked for deletion ("*.delete"). b) Use an internal queue of logs that contain directory names. Option 2.a is not attractive because most of the time the directory scan will not result anything to delete. Besides it's IO heavy. 

Therefore, the only reasonable option is to use 2.b where in an explicit `LinkedBlockingQueue` of logs is used in producer/consumer style. 

The current patch keeps track of IO failures during one run of deletion and retries the failed directories at the next scheduled run. `LinkedBlockingQueue` has O(1) `take` and `put`. This scheme is perhaps simpler than an explicitly synchronized access to a regular list. Alternatively, `removeFirstOccurance` could be used in O(1) time (in absence of failures) because always the head of the list will be `remove`d, terminating the search quickly.
close this PR because KAFKA-4360 also fix this bug
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.
Thanks @raghavgautam . Merged into trunk. Did you open a infra ticket for this.
@ijuma Updated comments.

I think it's great to be able to run the system tests in Travis. However, I don't understand why we added the gradle wrapper? It's the wrong version (we are using Gradle 3.2) and it was an intentional decision to remove it some time ago. Also, the system test renames are a bit arbitrary and they make it harder to use in the normal case, which is a point that Ewen had raised in the mailing list discussion.
Cc @ewencp
@manub according to [the plan](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Time+Based+Release+Plan) it is January 2017

Thanks for the PR. A few comments:

1. We need to maintain compatibility, so the older parameter should be supported but deprecated.
2. It would be great to do the same change for any other class that uses `--broker-list` (`VerifiableConsumer`, `VerifiableProducer`, etc.)
3. It would be good to update the documentation and system tests to use `bootstrap-server`.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.1 branches after minor style tweaks to the test.

@enothereska @mjsax @guozhangwang.

This follows the design as proposed in the KIP. 
Some key things:
 I've extracted all of the `Segment` functionality out of `RocksDBWindowStore` and into `Segments`. I've introduced a new class `SegmentedBytesStore` that both the `RocksDBWindowStore` and `RocksDBSessionStore` delegate to. They are wrappers on top of the `SegmentedBytesStore` that know how to deal with the specifics to those stores, i.e., iterators, key layout etc.
The new class `SessionWindows` doesn't derive from `Windows` as it doesn't make sense to pass a `SessionWindows` instance to the non-sesssion-window aggregate methods on `KGroupedStream`

Thanks
@manub I have raised https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2164 to get this change onto the 0.10.1.x patch release in order to get timely access to the kafka libs on 2.12.
Thanks @leachbj - this will unblock a bunch of downstream libraries! Keeping an eye on this.
@junrao any feedback about the comments? Thanks.
@hachikuji Could you address the comments above? Thanks.
Thanks @ijuma @becketqin @junrao !
Call for review @guozhangwang
Thanks @dguy . @guozhangwang could you have a final look? Thanks.

kafka.producer.ProducerTest > testAsyncSendCanCorrectlyFailWithTimeout FAILED.
This is unrelated to streams or this PR.
@junrao can we get a +1 on this PR? I think these metrics are still very useful.
@dguy @guozhangwang please have a look if you can. Thanks.
Thanks @dguy

`tests/cluster_file.json` should also probably be under `tests/travis/` since it is highly specific to that configuration. It'd also generally be a good idea to run a test using the existing implementation when there's this much movement under these tests to make sure everything still works (and that there are the expected number of tests -- one of the easiest things to break when moving things around is that some things get lost in directories without proper `__init__.py` files and become unimportable).

Also, trunk doesn't build since we're missing various licenses in files that don't pass the rat check...


@ijuma @harshach Not sure if it's better to do the incremental cleanup or revert the original commit, but this at least gets us back to a buildable state so other PRs can get through.

@ewencp, thanks for the PR. I think I'd revert the original PR as we really should ensure all system tests are still running and that the renames are really needed before merging it.

I'll defer to you though as you know this area of the code best. If you think we should rather merge this PR, it LGTM.
@ewencp I will open a pull request for the rat issue asap and will open jira's for rest of the issues.

@raghavgautam Sorry, should have posted here, I filed https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2172 already, which also removes the gradle wrapper and gets things setup in Travis via the travis.yml. See discussion there about whether we want to incrementally sort this out or just back out the change and re-file the PR so we can work on it until we've addressed the concerns previously mentioned.
@ewencp I too filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4448 and started working on it.
@ewencp  @ijuma Renames are needed to split tests into smaller parts that finish in 50 mins. We will need support from ducktape to be able to run only a subset of tests at a time.

@raghavgautam, my take is that we should make the changes to ducktape instead of the ad-hoc renames. For example, how does someone choose where to add a system test given all these numbered folders? And how do we know if we're going over the 50 minutes threshold? I think these questions need to be answered before the code gets merged as we rely heavily on system tests to maintain Kafka's quality.

@raghavgautam Think about how junit test runners work. They can parallelize things but don't require the user to think about how to do it. Also, a number of issues with the current approach: why is 50 minutes the magic number? What if Travis is OK with it and I want faster turnaround time on my builds? Do we have to move all the files around again just to get that? (That actually messes with any regression tracking since the test name changes...) Why couldn't the number of workers be parameterized and independent of the test directories? What about when we add the parallel test runner and test runners that get tests utilizing a smaller # of workers per test might be able to execute their share faster? What about tests that are parameterized a lot and therefore generate a larger number of tests than can possibly complete in 50 minutes (i.e. your granularity is a single test file, so if that exceeds your limit we have to jump through hoops to break it up, even if it's a single test; things like upgrade tests could easily grow to this size over time).

I think everyone agrees with the benefit of having this run more cheaply via docker and in Travis. The point we were trying to make is that this seems to be tackling half of that problem at the wrong level, and a real fix in ducktape doesn't seem particularly hard to implement afaict -- we just need to be able to tell the test runner to run 1/N of the tests. For tests with significant skew in their run times this isn't perfects, but I think extreme skew isn't currently a problem based on one of the recent runs of the tests:

However, what it does reveal is that there are some parameterized tests that seem to take longer than others, so a decent breakdown that still has a trivial implementation assuming tests are approximately equal would have to take every 1/Nth test rather than take blocks of 1/N tests.

See [this ducktape PR](https://github.com/confluentinc/ducktape/pull/154) as an example of what I'm suggesting, which would remove all the changes required within the tests themselves and just require adding the `--subset=X --subsets=10` parameters when invoking ducktape, isolating any choices about how Travis runs the tests to the Travis-specific files (although we'd still be hard coding the choice of 10 test runners/Travis env matrix parameters into those files).
@ijuma @hachikuji Hopefully straightforward update to ensure we get accurate info into the release notes.
